hints_html:
How can we use the identity

\[\begin{aligned} \mathcal{L}(f^{(n)}(t))=s^nF(s)-s^{n-1}f(0)-\dots-f^{(n-1)}(0)\end{aligned}\]

to our advantage?
hints_raw:
How can we use the identity

:<math>
\mathcal{L}(f^{(n)}(t))=s^nF(s)-s^{n-1}f(0)-\dots-f^{(n-1)}(0)
</math>

to our advantage?
question: 5 (c)
sols_html:
From the chart at the end of the exam we have the following identity

\[\begin{aligned} \mathcal{L}(f^{(n)}(t))=s^nF(s)-s^{n-1}f(0)-\dots-f^{(n-1)}(0)\end{aligned}\]

and we should always consider this identity first if we see products of polynomials and transforms. Comparing this to what we have,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}s^2F(s)-2s-3,\end{aligned}\]

we see that since \(\displaystyle {}f(0)=2\) and \(\displaystyle {}f'(0)=3\) then

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}s^2F(s)-2s-3=\mathcal{L}(f''(t)).\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we have

\[\begin{aligned} G(s)=\exp(-4s)\mathcal{L}(f''(t)).\end{aligned}\]

We now need to compute \(\mathcal{L}^{-1}(G(s))\). Returning again to our chart we have the identity

\[\begin{aligned} \mathcal{L}^{-1}\left(\exp(-cs)F(s)\right)=u_c(t)f(t-c)\end{aligned}\]

where u_c is the Heaviside function defined as

\[\begin{aligned} u_c= \begin{cases} 0,&t<c\\ 1,&t\geq{}c \end{cases}.\end{aligned}\]

Using this identity, we can immediately write

\[\begin{aligned} g(t)=\mathcal{L}^{-1}(G(s))=\mathcal{L}^{-1}(\exp(-4s)\mathcal{L}(f''(t)))=u_4(t)f''(t-4).\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}g(5)=u_4(5)f''(1)=f''(1)=2.\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
From the chart at the end of the exam we have the following identity

:<math>
\mathcal{L}(f^{(n)}(t))=s^nF(s)-s^{n-1}f(0)-\dots-f^{(n-1)}(0)
</math>

and we should always consider this identity first if we see products of polynomials and transforms.  Comparing this to what we have,

:<math>
\displaystyle{}s^2F(s)-2s-3,
</math>

we see that since <math>\displaystyle{}f(0)=2</math> and <math>\displaystyle{}f'(0)=3</math> then

:<math>
\displaystyle{}s^2F(s)-2s-3=\mathcal{L}(f''(t)).
</math>

Therefore we have

:<math>
G(s)=\exp(-4s)\mathcal{L}(f''(t)).
</math>

We now need to compute <math>\mathcal{L}^{-1}(G(s))</math>.  Returning again to our chart we have the identity

:<math>
\mathcal{L}^{-1}\left(\exp(-cs)F(s)\right)=u_c(t)f(t-c)
</math>

where u_c is the Heaviside function defined as

:<math>
u_c=
\begin{cases}
0,&t<c\\
1,&t\geq{}c
\end{cases}.
</math>

Using this identity, we can immediately write

:<math>
g(t)=\mathcal{L}^{-1}(G(s))=\mathcal{L}^{-1}(\exp(-4s)\mathcal{L}(f''(t)))=u_4(t)f''(t-4).
</math>

Therefore we have that

:<math>
\displaystyle{}g(5)=u_4(5)f''(1)=f''(1)=2.
</math>
statement_html:
Let f and g be two functions satisfying the following conditions

\[\begin{aligned} f(0) = 2, \quad f'(0) = 3, \quad f''(1) = 2 \\ G(s) = e^{-4s}(s^2F(s)-2s-3)\end{aligned}\]

where F(s) and G(s) are the Laplace transforms of the functions f(t) and g(t), respectively. Find the value of g(5).
statement_latex:
Let \emph{f} and \emph{g} be two functions satisfying the following
conditions

\begin{align*}
f(0) = 2, \quad f'(0) = 3, \quad f''(1) = 2 \\
G(s) = e^{-4s}(s^2F(s)-2s-3)
\end{align*}

where \emph{F(s)} and \emph{G(s)} are the Laplace transforms of the
functions \emph{f(t)} and \emph{g(t)}, respectively. Find the value of
\emph{g(5)}.
statement_raw:
Let ''f'' and ''g'' be two functions satisfying the following conditions

:<math>
\begin{align}
f(0) = 2, \quad f'(0) = 3, \quad f''(1) = 2 \\
G(s) = e^{-4s}(s^2F(s)-2s-3)
\end{align}
</math>

where ''F(s)'' and ''G(s)'' are the Laplace transforms of the functions ''f(t)'' and ''g(t)'', respectively. Find the value of ''g(5)''.
